page.title: 04Mammals in Sefton Park
page.content: Eleven species of mammal have been recorded in Sefton Park and nine of these are fairly common. However, most are nocturnal. In daylight the most easily observed mammal in the park is the {brown rat. The larger{water vole}is found around the lakes and streams. The only other mammals likely to be seen by day are the{rabbits}near the palm house. At night {hedgehogs, field mice }and {field voles}come out of their hiding places to feed on fallen nuts, seeds and insects. The use of ultra-sound equipment has resulted in the detection of three species of{bat}in the park. These are the {noctule,}the {common pipistrelle and{Daubenton's bat. In the next decade it is thought that {grey squirrels}will become established in the park.
